channel.title: Wanted Features4Java

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:378785”]As has been said, string switches are already being implemented. As to this:

Would be also cool if you could do this:

int squids; squids.set(10);
instead of

squids = 10;

You can basically already do that as well with the Integer class. If that’s not good enough for you, you can always implement it yourself:

[code=java5]
class COUEInt{
int myInt;

 public void set(int newInt){
      myInt = newInt;
 }

}

[/code][/quote]
Integers are immutable

about multiple inheritance, the only true rational benefit i can see from that is mixins and composite behavior

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Canownueazy, post:25, topic:378785”]Anyway my idea is to use an annotation.
@operator("+")

or

@operator({"+","-","^"})

If you added the annotation you would have to have the method present in the class.

operator+() {
//Stuff to do
}[/quote]
That would kinda break the concept of annotation processing.

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Canownueazy, post:25, topic:378785”][quote author=_s link=topic=474644.msg3475035#msg3475035 date=1295627091]

Yeah I’d like multiple inherit and operator overloading (not like stupid C++, I want to be able to EASILY do it, and create custom symbols ect)

custom operators would be retarded and you’d always get some retards trying to look cool by implementing a 8==D operator.

int i = 0, u = 2; i = i 8==D u;

but that beside it would make things very messy with new operators being shoved left, right and centre.
[/quote]Doesn’t matter

People don’t follow conventions?

People can do whatever they want to do in programming, though it may not be the best thing to do. People who actually want to use custom operators for tasks that can get confusing can.

Anyway my idea is to use an annotation.
@operator("+")

or

@operator({"+","-","^"})

If you added the annotation you would have to have the method present in the class.

operator+() {
//Stuff to do
}[/quote]

you single handedly proved how bad your ideas are, i didn’t even have to reply commenting on the flaws however i’ll just say that in a big project defining custom operators will turn elegant code into spaghetti-soup within a matter of lines.

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @k0_twin k0 twin
item.description:
@k0_twin wrote:

[quote=“Canownueazy, post:25, topic:378785”][quote author=_s link=topic=474644.msg3475035#msg3475035 date=1295627091]

Yeah I’d like multiple inherit and operator overloading (not like stupid C++, I want to be able to EASILY do it, and create custom symbols ect)

custom operators would be retarded and you’d always get some retards trying to look cool by implementing a 8==D operator.

int i = 0, u = 2; i = i 8==D u;

but that beside it would make things very messy with new operators being shoved left, right and centre.
[/quote]Doesn’t matter

People don’t follow conventions?

People can do whatever they want to do in programming, though it may not be the best thing to do. People who actually want to use custom operators for tasks that can get confusing can.[/quote]
The problem with this is that in the professional world proper conventions are pretty much a necessity. The same with documentation. If someone else can’t understand your code then that means it’s stuck to your brain, and not of much worth to your employer in some cases.

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @Canownueazy Canownueazy
item.description:
@Canownueazy wrote:

[quote="_s, post:24, topic:378785"][quote author=Canownueazy link=topic=474644.msg3473734#msg3473734 date=1295495216]
Yeah I’d like multiple inherit and operator overloading (not like stupid C++, I want to be able to EASILY do it, and create custom symbols ect)
[/quote]

custom operators would be retarded and you’d always get some retards trying to look cool by implementing a 8==D operator.

int i = 0, u = 2; i = i 8==D u;

but that beside it would make things very messy with new operators being shoved left, right and centre.[/quote]Doesn’t matter

People don’t follow conventions?

People can do whatever they want to do in programming, though it may not be the best thing to do. People who actually want to use custom operators for tasks that can get confusing can.

Anyway my idea is to use an annotation.
@operator("+")

or

@operator({"+","-","^"})

If you added the annotation you would have to have the method present in the class.

operator+() {
//Stuff to do
}

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Canownueazy:

Yeah I’d like multiple inherit and operator overloading (not like stupid C++, I want to be able to EASILY do it, and create custom symbols ect)

Operator overloading can get messy, to the point where you have no idea what you are doing with a + sign, which is why it’s better to just use method calls.

But multiple inheritance is a horrible idea, and can’t be implemented in a consistent way, I’m not going to bother explaining it, but I’ll link you to the wikipedia article and you can go from there:

en.wikipedia.org

Multiple inheritance

Multiple inheritance is a feature of some object-oriented computer programming languages in which an object or class can inherit characteristics and features from more than one parent object or parent class. It is distinct from single inheritance, where an object or class may only inherit from one particular object or class. Multiple inheritance has been a sensitive issue for many years, with opponents pointing to its increased complexity and ambiguity in situations such as the "diamond problem",...

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @JaydenD12 JaydenD12
item.description:
@JaydenD12 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:18, topic:378785”][quote author=JaydenD12 link=topic=474644.msg3473917#msg3473917 date=1295522684]
I hope they implement C#'s getting and setting. (I doubt it though)

C#:

private string name = "Jayden";

public string Name
{
	get { return name; }
	set { name = value; }
}

Java:

[code=java]private String name = “Jayden”;

public String getName() {
return name;
}

public String setName(String value) {
name = value;
}[/code]
[/quote]
do you have to do every variable in such a godawful manner for getting and setting in C#? if so its another reason for me to never touch it.[/quote]

You don’t have to do it like that, but I prefer to.

Read full topic

}[/code][/quote]

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

As has been said, string switches are already being implemented. As to this:

[quote=“Canownueazy, post:1, topic:378785”]Would be also cool if you could do this:

int squids; squids.set(10);
instead of

squids = 10;

You can basically already do that as well with the Integer class. If that’s not good enough for you, you can always implement it yourself:

class COUEInt{
     int myInt;

     public void set(int newInt){
          myInt = newInt;
     }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Wanted Features4Java
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote="_s, post:10, topic:378785"]oh my god how the fuck does set make a program flow any more than an equals sign you retard.

worthy suggestions please… closures (which were rejected and i have no clue why), some people argue for multiple inheritance (although i’m not one of them, what’s the point when you can use implements). what else… operator overloading is what some people want but that’s ugly lol, others really want an api cleanup & overhaul which i definitely agree with. these improvements matter, yours hardly do[/quote]
Closures weren’t rejected. They’re being postponed, due to “Plan B”. http://openjdk.java.net/projects/jdk7/features/#deferred

Read full topic
